Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Collaborative Research: Next generation 2D-LC with greatly improved quantitative performance: Innovations in hardware, software, and methodology
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Dwight Stoll of Gustavus Adolphus College and Sarah Rutan of Virginia Commonwealth University are studying fundamental aspects of the quantitative performance of two-dimensional liquid chromatography (2D-LC). 2D-LC is an analytical methodology used for separation of inherently complex materials including urine, blood, urban wastewater, and the products of chemical and biological synthesis. The separation power of 2D-LC is well suited to better understand such complex samples in fields ranging from medicine and pharmaceutical development to environmental chemistry. However, state-of-the-art 2D-LC currently suffers from poorer sensitivity and precision compared to more conventional methods, and this limits its scope of application. This academic/industrial collaboration between Gustavus Adolphus College, Virginia Commonwealth University, and Agilent Technologies will enable a deeper fundamental understanding of these limitations and support the development of novel technologies to improve the quantitative performance of 2D-LC.

This project will leverage the strengths of the collaboration partners to address the limitations in quantitative performance of 2D-LC through a combination of complementary strategies. Simulations will be developed to better understand the underlying fundamental limitations of coupling the two dimensions in 2D-LC, novel valve technology will be developed and its performance characterized experimentally, and computer-based data analysis methods will be developed that enable better utilization of the multi-dimensional structure of data produced by 2D-LC methods. It is expected that the detection limits of 2D-LC will be improved at least five-fold, and that the quantitative precision will be improved so that it is competitive with conventional liquid chromatography. The broader impacts of the work include: wider application of 2D-LC as a high resolution separation technique across the life sciences and chemical industries; engagement of students at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels in cutting-edge research; and development of simulations that will facilitate more efficient and deeper learning about critical concepts in liquid chromatography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project focused on improving the quantitative performance of two-dimensional liquid chromatography (2D-LC), a developing method for the analysis of complex mixtures. Detailed investigations of the performance and optimization of an active solvent modulation valve that couples the two dimensions of separation were carried out, in collaboration with Prof. Dwight Stoll at Gustavus Adolphus College and Agilent Corporation. One focus of the work carried out at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) involved the development of an advanced chromatographic computer simulator.  This simulator, in particular, provides investigators a detailed understanding of the impact of solvent mismatch issues when coupling the two separation dimensions, ultimately allowing for accelerated optimization of new 2D-LC methods. In the most recent work, a global model for the injection profiles produced by the active solvent modulation valve was developed, which enhances the performance of the simulator.

Various projects have described the development and application of data analysis strategies for the large, multidimensional data sets produced by 2D-LC instruments. An investigation of the levels of furanocoumains in vegetables allowed for the determination of fundamental performance characteristics of both the 2D-LC technology and the data analysis algorithms.  As mass spectrometry is frequently used for identifying and quantifying analytes after chromatographic separation, methods were developed specifically to use the data resulting from high resolution mass spectrometric instruments. Novel algorithms were developed for this purpose. Key variables in the successful application of these methods are the degree of chromatographic overlap and spectral similarity.  To this end, a technique for the rational design of mixtures was developed to optimize the mixtures used for chromatographic method optimization.

This project's broader impacts included contributions to the enhancement of STEM workforce by training three VCU Ph.D. students and five VCU undergraduate students in analytical chemistry, material science, chromatography, and simulations.  Three of these undergraduates now attend graduate school in chemistry; two of the PhD students are currently employed in industry, and one will graduate in 2021.  These students especially benefited from the collaborative nature of the project, by having access to three faculty members for mentoring (Stoll at Gustavus and Rutan and Collinson at VCU). Project participants worked collaboratively together sharing knowledge through group meeting presentations, phone conversations, in-person visits, and writing joint scientific papers.  A total of 7 peer-reviewed manuscripts have been published to date from work undertaken at VCU.  Additional broader impacts lie in the development of the commercially available active solvent modulation valve and characterization of its performance.  A broad range of investigators in the fields of medicine, environmental science, food science, and agriculture have access to a powerful tool for the characterization of complex mixtures.
